name: Red Root Floater
description: Phyllanthus fluitans, commonly known as Red Root Floater, is a free-floating aquatic plant native to South America, particularly the Amazon Basin in Brazil, Colombia, and Venezuela. It belongs to the Phyllanthaceae family and features small, round to oval, bright green leaves (1-2 cm across) that float on the water surface. The leaves have a slightly wavy margin and grow in pairs along branching stems. The most distinctive feature is the bright red roots that hang freely in the water, providing striking visual contrast. The plant displays a rosette-like growth habit and forms dense floating mats. Under high light, the leaves can develop red or bronze tints. In its native habitat, it grows floating on the surface of still or slow-moving water bodies in tropical regions. In terrariums or indoor settings, this plant adds vibrant colors with its red roots and can provide shade and natural filtration. It's popular in aquascaping for its unique appearance and fast growth.
careTips: Small floating plant - no substrate needed, roots hang freely in water
Red roots add striking color contrast - most vibrant under high light
Needs moderate to high light (2-3 watts per gallon) for best growth and red coloration
Fast growing - can quickly cover water surface, trim regularly to control
Native to Amazon Basin (Brazil, Colombia, Venezuela) - prefers warm water (22-28Â°C)
Prefers pH 6.0-7.5 and soft to moderately hard water (2-12 dGH)
Benefits from regular fertilization - absorbs nutrients through roots from water
CO2 supplementation beneficial but not required
Non-toxic and safe for all aquarium inhabitants
Can be used in aquariums, paludariums, and ripariums
Propagates via stolons (runners) - daughter plants form on stolons
If roots lose red color, increase light intensity
Requires some water movement to prevent stagnant conditions
Leaves may develop red/bronze tints under high light conditions
